content.description: Liebacking and edging up a crack to a thought provoking highstep that gets you over the undercut summit block. Might be 2 star worthy once it cleans up.
content.location: On the east face around the first large arete you pass under as you walk beneath the Moran mesa. Look for a jagged crack with holds that leads to a high finish over an undercut topout block.

content.description: Right hand on right arete to high left hand slot/edge on the face. Highstep and lieback right edge to reach good summit holds.
content.location: Problem is on the white south face of an obvious block that has detached from the left side of the famous mesa that lies beyond and below the tourist viewpoint. Route faces the tourist viewpoint.

content.description: Okay finger and hand cracks plus a face climb or two. Pretty sure nothing's harder than VO+, but I could be wrong.
content.location: Right off the north end of the big ledge directly below the Moran point tourist railing. Routes generally face the famous Moran Point mesa.

content.description:
Start on low holds below the mono pocket where the two cracks intersect. Pull on and into the mono, which is surprisingly friendly, and continue up the vertical crack to some top out jugs. 

  It might be a good idea to inspect the top out of this one for sandy holds before climbing it.
content.location: On the right side of the moran point boulder, locate a thin vertical crack intersected by a horizontal crack at about 6' in height. A mono pocket is located at the point of intersection.

content.description: The most readily available boulder problem at Moran Point. Surely your next tinder date will love this photo! You’re so brave! Can you teach me how to do that?I sure can:Start on some edges or sloping side pulls below the finger crack. Climb your way into the crack for some sweet locks and jugs. Get your photo taken. Great holds lead to an easy top out.
content.location: Find your way to the right side of the Moran Point boulder, and look for a finger crack, starting at about 6'.

content.description: Amazing bouldering on perfect white porcelain Limestone. It was at this site in 1540, that Coronado and his band of conquistadors became the first Europeans to ever lay eyes on the largest canyon in the world. It took them four years to hike from Mexico city in search of the legendary 7 sacred cities of gold. Lead by Native Hopi Indians, they camped on the rim for four months trying to reach the river unsuccessfully.
